questions.text: Under which initiative are acute respiratory illness, malnutrition & diarrhea managed in children aged 0 to 5 years?

choices.text: Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI)
National Vector Borne Disease Control Program (NVBDCP)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI)

Explanation:

The child is 2 years old and weighs only 6 kg; therefore, he is severely malnourished. Frequent watery stools suggest he has diarrhea, and the cough, runny nose, and sore throat suggest he has an Acute Respiratory Infection (ARI).

  • The IMNCI is a strategy that comprehensively manages the most common and serious conditions affecting children under 5 years of age.
  • This includes diseases like
    • ARI (pneumonia)
    • Diarrhea
    • Measles
    • Malaria
    • Malnutrition

The Expanded Program on Immunization (EPI) (Option A) is a global initiative that ensures the immunization of all children against common vaccine-preventable diseases. While EPI focuses on vaccination, it does not encompass the broader management of illnesses like pneumonia or malnutrition beyond their prevention through immunization.

National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) (Option B) is an Indian initiative designed to improve healthcare delivery across rural areas. While NRHM encompasses various programs and missions, including those targeting maternal and child health, but it is not specifically focused on the integrated management of illnesses like pneumonia and malnutrition in children.

National Vector Borne Disease Control Program (NVBDCP) (Option D) focuses on preventing and controlling vector-borne diseases such as malaria, dengue, and chikungunya.

questions.text: A distressed mother brings her 6-month-old son to the emergency. She complains that he has been refusing to feed, vomiting, and passing frequent loose stools for the past 2 days. He also had a bout of convulsions an hour ago. On examination, the baby is lethargic and difficult to wake. Which among his symptoms is not a danger sign?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Frequent loose stools

Explanation:

Under IMNCI, The following are considered to be the danger signs in children under 5 years of age

  • Convulsions
  • Lethargy/unconsciousness
  • Inability to drink/breastfeed
  • Vomiting

Urgent referral after starting initiation of first dose of antibiotic is needed in case of  severe diseases.

While frequent loose stools (Diarrhea) can indicate an issue such as dehydration or infection and should not be ignored, the other symptoms (lethargy and difficulty waking, refusal to feed, and convulsions) are more immediately concerning and are clear danger signs requiring urgent medical attention under the IMNCI act.

Lethargy & difficulty in waking (Option A) could indicate severe dehydration, or infection (such as meningitis or sepsis).

Refusal to feed (Option B) can quickly lead to dehydration and malnutrition.

Convulsions (Option C) indicate abnormal brain activity, which can be due to a variety of causes including high fever (febrile seizures), electrolyte imbalances, infections (like meningitis), or other neurological issues.

questions.text: A mother brings her 10-month-old daughter to the clinic with complaints of refusal to feed and vomiting everything for the past 2 days. On examination, she is lethargic and also has fever. According to the IMNCI color coding system, how should this child be classified?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pink (Severe illness)

Explanation:

The IMNCI guidelines use a color-coded system to classify the severity of illness in children.

Therefore, if a child has any of the danger signs, he should be classified as PINK (Severe illness) and given an Urgent referral after starting initial treatment.

This child is refusing to breastfeed and also vomits everything. Additionally, she is lethargic. All these are danger signs and warrant urgent treatment. Hence, Pink (Severe illness).

Green (Mild illness) (Option A)

  • Mild illness typically includes conditions that are not immediately life-threatening and can be managed with home care.

  • This includes children with minor symptoms such as a mild cough without fast breathing or chest indrawing, minor diarrhea without dehydration, and other non-severe conditions. The child in the scenario has signs & symptoms of severe illness. Therefore, the child does not fit into the green category of mild illness.

Yellow (Moderate illness) (Option B)

  • Moderate illness includes conditions that require medical treatment but do not necessitate immediate hospital referral.

  • This might include conditions like pneumonia without chest indrawing (fast breathing but no chest indrawing), mild dehydration, and moderate malnutrition.

Orange (Moderate illness) (Option D)

  • IMNCI categorizes/color codes moderate Illness as yellow and not orange.

questions.text: A child aged 2 months was brought to the PHC by his mother. She reports that he has been very fussy and irritable for the past 3 days. Initially, she noticed that he had a mild cough and a runny nose. Over the past 24 hours, his symptoms worsened and he is breathing rapidly. O/E the child is lethargic and irritable. His respiratory rate was 70/minute, chest drawing was present. The most appropriate line of management for this patient is.

choices.text: Classify as pneumonia and refer urgently to secondary level hospital.
Classify as pneumonia, start antibiotic, and advise to report after 2 days
Classify as very severe pneumonia, start antibiotics, and refer urgently.
Classify as severe pneumonia and keep the baby warm.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Classify as very severe pneumonia, start antibiotics, and refer urgently.

Explanation:

The IMNCI classification of Pneumonia is as follows:

  • Fast Breathing guidelines:
    • Infants under 2 months: More than or equal to 60 bpm
    • Infants 2–12 months: More than or equal to 50 bpm
    • Infants 12–59 months: More than or equal to 40 bpm

This child is lethargic and irritable on examination, which is a danger sign, also he has chest indrawing and an increased respiratory rate (70/min). Hence he would be classified as Very Severe Disease or Severe Pneumonia and a dose of antibiotic should be started and urgently referred to the hospital.

Classify as pneumonia and refer urgently to secondary level hospital (Option A) and Classify as pneumonia, start antibiotic, and advise to report after 2 days (Option B): incorrect as they signify “pneumonia” as per the aforementioned table.

Classify as severe pneumonia and keep the baby warm (Option D): correctly classifies it as under severe pneumonia but is partially incorrect as the baby needs to be urgently referred to a hospital.

questions.text: A 3yr old boy was brought to the clinic for complaints of cough and runny nose. He is otherwise healthy and is on schedule with his vaccinations. On examination, he had rapid breathing and was restless. Which of the following is considered to be fast breathing in children of 1 to 5 years of age?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Respiratory rate > 40/min

Explanation:

  • Fast breathing is a vital sign indicating respiratory distress in pediatric patients
  • In children 1-5 years of age, a respiratory rate of >40/min is considered fast breathing
  • It signifies respiratory distress and warrants further evaluation and management

The other options are incorrect as per the rule of 60, 50, 40. (Option A, C and D ruled out)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about latent TB?

A) 10% people with latent TB can develop active TB

B) Individual can spread TB to others

C) Alpha interferon test will be positive

D) The bacilli are non-dormant
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A and C

Explanation:

Latent TB:

  • Latent TB - A condition in which an individual is infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis (M. TB) but does not have active TB disease.
  • Individuals with latent TB are asymptomatic and not contagious. (Statement B)
  • Approximately 40% of the population have latent TB
  • Key Characteristics of Latent TB:
    • The bacilli are dormant. (Statement D)
    • Individuals with latent TB are non-infectious.
    • Around 10% of individuals infected with latent TB eventually develop active TB. (Statement A)
  • Tests for Latent TB:
    • Tuberculin skin test
    • Alpha interferon test (Statement C)

questions.text: Tuberculin conversion index aka Annual risk of infection (ARI) is a measure of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Incidence of TB Infection

Explanation:

Tuberculin conversion index aka Annual risk of infection (ARI) is a measure of Incidence of TB Infection.

questions.text: In which of the following is the tuberculin test considered negative?

choices.text: 12 mm induration in a HIV negative drug abuser
10 mm induration in a 2 year old child
8 mm induration in a patient with silicosis
5 mm induration in a person with recent contact with active TB

questions.solution:
Answer: (C) 8 mm induration in a patient with silicosis

Explanation:

≥10 mm induration in a patient with silicosis is considered positive. Since in the question an induration of size 8mm is mentioned, it will be considered negative in a patient of Silicosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old healthcare worker with rheumatoid arthritis is started on immunosuppressive therapy. What is the most appropriate reason to perform a two-step tuberculin skin test (TST) before initiating treatment?

choices.text: To assess the patient's baseline immunity against tuberculosis
To confirm a recent positive TST result
To differentiate between a boosted reaction and a new infection
To monitor the effectiveness of immunosuppressive therapy on latent tuberculosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) To differentiate between a boosted reaction and a new infection

Explanation:

Before starting immunosuppressive therapy, a two-step tuberculin skin test (TST) is used to distinguish between a boosted reaction from prior exposure to tuberculosis and a new infection. This approach helps confirm a positive TST result, preventing unnecessary treatment for latent tuberculosis due to misinterpretation.

  • 1st test - read within 48 to 72 hours
    • If positive - consider the patient infected.
    • If negative - 2nd test after 3 weeks.
  • 2nd test - read within 48 to 72 hours - done after 3 weeks.
    • Positive - infected
    • Negative - uninfected

  • To assess the patient's baseline immunity against tuberculosis(Option A): The TST does not assess "immunity" in the protective sense, but rather latent infection. Immunity would relate more to BCG vaccination or T-cell responses.

  •  To confirm a recent positive TST result(Option B): That would be a repeat single TST, not a two-step test.

  • To monitor the effectiveness of immunosuppressive therapy on latent tuberculosis(Option D): TST is not used to monitor treatment effectiveness. Also, immunosuppression can cause false negatives in TST.
